author: Lumix
title: Most powerful starfighter in the galaxy!
review:
I have made a complete, very detailed review here:
http://www.hispalug.com/foro/index.php?topic=8809.0

The review includes many photos both of the building process and the complete model, animated GIFs to show playability and also a video.

The TIE Defender is one of the most powerful starfighers in the Star Wars galaxy. It can outmanouver A-Wings or TIE Interceptors, and it is more heavily armed and resilient than the X-Wing or B-Wing. 

The building process is not very lengthy, but fully enjoyable. It has no complicated steps. First, you have to build the body of the ship, then the cockpit and finally the three sets of wings, which are identical, so be prepared to repeat some steps here. You can see many photos of the building process, the box and the instruction manual in this gallery:
http://www.brickshelf.com/cgi-bin/gallery.cgi?f=411894

The finished model is medium-sized, and looks very cool and menacing. The ship utilizes the new TIE color-scheme (black and grey). There are no stickers. Here's an image of the finished model:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080483.jpg

Rear view. The ION engine is well-designed:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080528.jpg

The set has two minifigs, a stormtrooper and a new TIE-pilot. Here's a comparison with TIE Pilot from 4479 - TIE Bomber.
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080497.jpg

You can open the cockpit to have access to the pilot minifig, as seen in this animated GIF. There are no controls or levers inside the cockpit:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080507a.gif

The cockpit can rotate, like the 6208 - BWing's cockpit. 
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080521a.gif

This set is pretty swoosheable, and resembles the TIE Defender, although the wings could be a bit bigger, and the set could be less skeletal, specially in the joints between the wings and the hull. The ship may rest horizontally on one or two of its wings; It can also rest vertically on the rear part of all wings:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080509.jpg

Here's a comparison with the "real" TIE Defender, so that you can make yourself and idea of the set's accuracy:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080546.jpg

There is one flick-missile at each wing's tip, totalizing 6 flick-missiles. They also serve as laser / ion cannons:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080532a.gif

Here's a comparison with the 8017 - Vader's TIE:
http://www.brickshelf.com/gallery/Lumix/STAR-WARS/8087/p1080547.jpg

Last but not least, I've uploaded a video where you can see this set's playability:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9wr4H6071g

PROS
- Very original, cool design.
- Cockpit can rotate.
- 6 flick-missiles.
- Proper colour scheme.
- New imperial pilot minifig.
- No stickers.

CONS
- The zone where the wings link to the hull could be thicker.
- No controls or levers inside the cockpit.
- Pricey.

I recommend this set. It is a must specially if you're building your TIE armada. Not bad for one of the first Star Wars 2010 sets: Nice design, good recreation of this mighty starfighter, pretty swoosheable and including a new minifig. Full gallery here:
http://www.brickshelf.com/cgi-bin/gallery.cgi?f=411893

author: MBlazier620
title: The Empire Strikes Back... And Hard
review: One of the best sets released with the upcoming starwars sets. I bought this the day it came out and I must say I'm quite impressed. The color scheme is on the money and the design is very symmetrical, although I must say the wings support is a little shabby and needs stronger connection. All in all i give this set a 5/5 although it has its flaws, its pros make up for it. A great addition to any collection!!

author: legoclone
title: OK - but a little lacking for the price
review: This isn’t a bad addition to the imperial fighter fleet.  I do like the new Tie pilot (his helmet is basically a black version of the larger helmet you get with the AT-AT driver in the new battle pack.).  The Defender is a fairly easy build and I like all the extra firepower included on it. I also like the friction-lock hinge used on the cockpit as opposed to one on earlier Tie Fighters. I do feel like they cheapened out on the inside of the cockpit though. Basically the pilot sits there with no seat and no controls in front of him.  He just sits there looking out the front window like he’s in his living room.   That’s going to require some fixing. Come on Lego…if you’re going to charge $50 for a 300-piece set (which is a little steep) at least don’t skimp on the little details like that.

author: ChrisBricks1138
title: A Rebel Pilots Worst Nightmare!
review:
I just got the new Tie Defender from legoshop.co.uk and at first, was surprised at the price. That didn't last long. This is an exceptional set, which has been begging for release as a LEGO set ever since we saw it in Battlefront: Renegade Squadron.

PROS:

Spinning wings
Six flick fire missiles that actually work!
New TIE Pilot helmet design
Inclusion of a Stormtrooper minifigure
Perfect cockpit design
Comic in back of instruction booklet

CONS:

No controls inside the cockpit
....um.....thats all!

Overall, this ship is perfect both for its play features, and as a display piece, and is a must have for a LEGO Star Wars or Expanded Universe fan, and is an awesome addition to the TIE 'Family'

author: jacobiscool4
title: its okay
review:
its okay, but you really need something to go against it. if you get it, be prepared for building the same thing three times.

pros:
- 6 missles
- 2 laser cannons
- new tie pilot

cons:
- lame
- not fun to build

author: fox171171
title: Not perfect, but overall a nice addition to the TIE fleet...
review:
I've been collecting LEGO since the 70's/80's (mostly classic space back then, pretty much all Star Wars now). This is my first review.

I loved the X-Wing and TIE Fighter games and was really looking forward to this set. Took me about an hour to build, but I was interrupted a bit. The build is a bit repetitive as you might imagine, but I built the wings concurrently rather than one after another and that made it seem less monotonous. It's a bit smaller than I expected.

Pros:

  • Looks pretty good (though not spot on)
  • Grey trim instead of blue
  • Nice to get a stormtrooper in addition to the pilot. Can't have too many.
  • Wings solidly attached.
  • Cockpit parts in a separate bag from the wing parts (so somewhat pre-sorted)

Cons:

  • Cost me about CDN$70, a bit high for what you get
  • Rotating cockpit. Why?
  • Low detail (no detail) cockpit interior. Exterior blocky.
  • Attachment points for wings could look better.
  • Pilot's helmet is huge!

While it's nice that the instruction manuals have become clearer lately, when there is only a single part in a step, that's not a step! I guess it is better being too simplified than confusing though. I can't see any reason for the cockpit to rotate, and it ends up not quite centered sometimes. (Aside from landing, I never saw a point to the rotating B-Wing cockpit either.) The flick fire missiles should be the twin ion cannons and quad lasers, but I imagine they are!

author: MandalorianCandidate
title: Defend this...
review:
I’ll start off by giving a disclaimer:  I’ve never been a big fan of the TIE Fighter in Lego form.  Sure, it was nice to have the Darth Vader TIE Fighter come out as one of the first sets and then a couple of years later to get the regular TIE Fighter.  But as I think about it more, it was really because we were getting Darth Vader in minifig form and then the Stormtrooper (finally!).  Now that these minifigs are pretty ubiquitous the sets they come with are kind of ‘meh.’

 

With the TIE Defender, it’s more of the same ‘meh.’

 

The biggest hang-up with this set is the price.  There’s no way in H-E-double hockey sticks that this thing should be priced at $50—just plain ridiculous.  “Well,” you may wonder, “maybe there’s some specialty pieces made just for this fighter.”  I can find only one unique part, and that’s the TIE Pilot helmet (more about that in a sec.).  The rest, for the most part, are pretty standard, even the cockpit windshield and hatch cover are recycled from previous sets.  The only justification I can see is that Lego may think this will not sell very well outside the collector/hard core SW fan market so they upped the price.  It’s not an exclusive at Toys R Us so I don’t see the justification.

 

Along with the price, the huge box the set comes in is sort of a letdown.  It makes you think that the ship will be huge, otherwise why the large box?  I think it’s to justify the high price.  If you’re going to drop that much coin on a set, you’re going to want it to be big or unique or have some awesome features.  A smaller box will definitely temper the will to plunk down $50.

 

If you do end up getting the set, please wait for a great sale or clearance.  The price isn’t justifiable.  I got it for $30 at Borders using one of their common email coupons.  In fact, $30 is more the right cost for what you get.  (BTW, the price per piece ratio is 16.4 cents—304 pieces comes included).

 

Besides the cost, the other down side is the relatively uninteresting build.  There are two different segments:  the cockpit and the fins.  The cockpit is not that big and doesn’t have a unique feel to it.  I haven’t built my new 8017 Vader TIE yet so I don’t know how its cockpit compares, but the 8087 is reminiscent of previous TIEs.  The most interesting portion is the Technic parts used for the ‘engine’ or cockpit swivel piece in the back.  There are two propeller-like pieces that come together with two Technic wheel pieces with pegs that hold everything together very sturdily.  The fins have two symmetric panels in each build that hook together to a central panel that clips on to pegs built into the cockpit swivel assembly.  So when you build one, you just repeat it two more times.  I knew it going into the build that it would be a little monotonous, but it was OK.  Actually, having triplets of most of the parts made part-hunting in the pile easy and quick.  I think I built it in less than an hour (I like to watch TV, usually something SW-related, to give the experience some ambiance).

 

What I really like about the set is the new TIE Pilot helmet.  It is rather interesting—an amalgam of the Rebel Pilot helmet combined with the face plate of the updated Stormtrooper.  I believe it’s the black version of the AT-AT Driver helmet in the new 8084 Snowtrooper battle pack.  Thank you Lego for the great improvement.  I was never fond of the old TIE Pilots as they were just black stormtroopers with a crummy paint job.  This new one has some good detail to it, although the chest piece is still the same one used before.

 

Other pluses and things to consider:

  • I also like the new color scheme.  The black and light blay is more visually appealing than the older black and blue.  I like that this one matches the 8017 DV TIE as well.  I am hoping that this signals that the TIE Bomber, Interceptor, and Fighter will all be redone the same way (not at the same price point, though).
  • The cockpit swivel feature is a nice touch.  It helps the swooshability factor to go up, although the bulkiness of the three fins pushes it down too.  Having it swivel means that it can be displayed with it sitting on one set of fins or two.  However, with the cockpit open it becomes top heavy and can flip over if the hatch is not pushed back all the way so it can catch on the fin assembly.
  • Not a fan of the flick fire but this comes with six, one for each fin.
  • NO STICKERS.  HUZZAH!

 

Only one other minifig comes with this one, a stormtrooper.  I guess Lego could have gone the way of the 7674 V-19 Torrent and included one minifig, but for the price…you really would like to have more.  What I would suggest is to have something like the 6208 B-Wing that has a base component with it.  That way you could justify the higher price and could have included an Empire technician like the ones that came with the 7264 Imperial Inspection.  Then the stormtrooper could have ‘something to do.’

 

For modders, there are tons of wing pieces and large panels but nothing diverse in terms of colored parts.

 

Again, my recommendation is get it for $30 but anything higher is not worth it.

 

Borrowing the rating method from fbtb.net...

price/parts ratio - 3/10
parts selection - 6/10
minifigs - 4/10

construction - 5/10
design/sturdiness - 7/10
comparison to video game - 8/10
swoosh factor - 6/10
reviewer's tilt - 7/10
FINAL SCORE – 5.8/10 ==> 3 of 5

author: blazetrooper501
title: BEST tie vehicle yet
review:
This set is awsome overall I would get this.

 

pros

new tie defender pilot helmet

stormtrooper

6 missles

 

cons

 

you have to build the wings 3 times.

author: benjadude11
title: If I have to make one more tie defender wing I swear... bad things will happen.
review:
I was all ready to purchase my new ARC-170 Starfighter from my local toy store when , all of a sudden, i glance at the price tag on the nearby Tie Defender. Then I look at the ARC-170. Then the Tie Defender. I look at the comparative sizes of each box. I walk back to the shelf, put down the ARC-170, and pick up the Tie Defender.

I would do this review in parts, like normal, but this set only has one part, so I'll skip the boldface headings for once.

The set includes two figs, the classic stormtrooper and the fancy new tie pilot. both have blank black faces underneath their helmets. The pilot has a new helmet that i have never seen before, with a small open part at the back, necessitating the black face to give him a complete look. The stormtrooper is old-school, just the way I like it. 
The ship's build is so repetitive that at the end I was twitching, and I built the third wing without looking at the instructions. The ship has three wings, which each branch into two parts, each with a mounted flickfire missile. They are attached to the cockpit in such a way so that if you hold the cockpit at the right angle you can spin the wings around and you get quite a nice breeze. the inside of the cockpit is AWFUL. the pilot can't even sit right, because some genius (sarcasm) put a red 1x4 piece with studs on the sides in back of him. What?!?! plus, there are no controls. not even a lever, for pete's sake. 

I don't know why I rated this set as high as I did, cause it really didn't deserve it. The set wasn't actually in any of the movies or even the TV show. I mean honestly. I couldn't even display the darn thing without building a stand for it. And there is no MOC potential whatsoever, because all of the pieces are thin and black or a trans-gray dome. 

Overall: It's not often that an entire set can be described with two keyboard characters, but I really feel that this one can. :P

author: BobaFett2
title: Great
review: Awesome set. I guarantee it. It's got great rolling movement, has 6 flick-fire missiles (or more), an opening cockpit, and 3 wings split into 6 wings. There are lots of good bricks. For building, there's not much, but it's fun to play with.

author: EtudeTheBadger
title: 'TIE Defender Standing By!'
review:
Finally! I've waited five long years for this fighter to be converted to LEGO, a wish all too fuelled by Empire At War: Forces of Corruption. I have been tempted to create my own Defender, but I decided to wait; LEGO would come around.
 

And they have!

First off, let me say that the Defender is a superb addition to any Star Wars fan collection. The fighter looks great in a combat reenactment against any Rebel craft (including an E-wing I built), the TIE Pilot included is excellent with his swanky new headgear and there's another stormtrooper to add to your collection (or your first stormtrooper if you're new). The structure of the ship is relatively sturdy and swooshable, and the cylinder engines look cool and so individual from the 'eye' thrusters of other TIEs over the years. It's also fun to make- an invaluable part of any model, really! Add to your Imperial Fleet- or, start a Zann Consortium Fleet!
 

Oh no. Here come the pessimistic slants. As always, there are some cons, I'm afraid. Firstly, flick-fire ordnance. Yuck. These missiles are the worst gimmick ever added to a LEGO range. Seriously, they have the firing range and force of a wingless gnat. Also, even if they did work like the blue-blazing torpedos seen in the films, they're ridiculously hard to fire from the wings. Getting a handhold ain't easy. Also, the cockpit spins. WHY?! The Defender is a fixed-wing craft (or so I think) and gets its inertia from actual manoevres in space. This feature made the fighter hard to move about properly. Also, the cockpit has no instrumentation- again, WHY?! 

Pros:

  • Looks cool in every way
  • TIE Pilot's helmet is fabulous- shame it's a first
  • Another Stormtrooper
  • Wings well built

Cons:
 

  • Missiles - ppppht
  • Wings slant about when moved- probably because of smooth tines
  • Cockpit spins- needless
  • Featureless cockpit- awwww

Don't worry- it's still super!

author: vid454
title: A great set for your collection!
review:
It's a great set if your a collector or you like TIE fighters. OK let's skip to the good part.

Building: It's fine to build, but it repeats when you'r building the wings.

Parts: There are some good parts for MOCs, new design on the TIE pilot (must like that) and an extra stormtrooper (respect that).

Playability: It's cool to play if you have more of these (I don't). The spinning cockpit is a neat feature. I hate the flick-fire missiles becouse they don't work so good.

Value for money: Two words: TO EXPENCIVE! They could have droped the price for about 20 euros.


Pros:
-new minifigure design,
-extra stormtrooper,
-cool parts,
-spinning cockpit.

Cons:
-building the wings,
-flick-fire missiles,
-EXPENSIVE price.

Overall a great set. I give it a 4 out of 5. Hope you find this helpfull.

author: Phantom
title: Good, but far from amazing
review:
Recently got this set on a sale for half price, which i think is the perfect price for it. I would never have gotten it if it wasnt for the decrease in price, nor do i reccomend getting it unless you can find it on a good offer because £40 is way over the top. The maximum this should be is £31.99. Apart from the price, this one is reasonobly good, there is nothing exactly wrong with it, but it should have more features. One thing is that the cockpit has NOTHING INSIDE IT, NOT EVEN 1 LEVER! You could easily put one beside the pilot, but basically, he looks stupid in there without nothing. Another thing is, what idiot though of putting a red brick with the studs facing towards to minifigures back?!? I had to remove and replace it with a normal brick of its size, in a gray colour, now it looks nowhere near as stupid.

one good thing about this is that it has no stickers! Woohoo, something rare of lego to do, but the printed pieces are nothing special, they are just recycled from other sets.

Minifigs are 1 stormtrooper, which has no definite reason to be there(but i still like it!) and a new, better looking tie pilot, he uses the same head as the at-at driver from the snowtrooper battlepack. No new body though, but the helmet looks better than the old one.

Now, onto the building. I started getting a headache from building all those stupid wings, and the build is VERY REPETIVE. The only non repetetive parts are the minifigures and the cockpit, which is small and only consists of a few pieces. The set however, is quite sturdy, compared to others, but the wings tend to fall off every other time you play with it, but they are easy to attach so im not gonna complain about this. The spinning feature isnt bad, it keeps the cockpit in the same place as you turn the wings, but on my one, it dosent look exactly right, because it goes slightly in the direction you are spinning the wings and then falls in line with them. This dosent detract from play though.

Overall, i think this set is missing quite a few important features, it looks rather stupid without them, so you would basically need a lever, and a four stud long gray brick to make it look better. it an ok set, but you would have to be stupid to pay £40 for it though, max ide say is £30, try looking for sales, its always on discount somewhere.

author: Inferno186
title: Coolest TIE Fighter on the market
review:
I thought this set was really cool, the wings are tedious to make but the end result is worth it. Overall it is a really good set, I only had 3 problems with it

1. I didn't like the spinning, i'm pretty sure the actual ship doesn't do that and for me it only gets in the way, however this can be fixed if you have the will and a spare brick or two

2. The inside of the cockpit is LAME, the pilot literally is just sitting on the edge, no controls nothing, plus there is a red brick with the pegs facing his back, but again can be fixed with some extra pieces

3. This goes for most all Legos nowadays but it is a little overpriced, I believe the set is $50 dollars or something like that when it should be $30-$40

Pros

Cool design

Sturdy

Extra stormtrooper


Cons

Spinning wings

Repetitive build

Lame cockpit

author: verguts
title: design before functionality
review:
A set you think will add value to your Star Wars Imperium, but the added value is rather low.

Pros

  • design: looks much like original design
  • Fits perfect with the TIE fighter and TIE interceptor

Cons

  • not stable: when put on surface or when held
  • how do you hold this thing when it flies?
  • difficult to place and remove figure from cockpit
  • repetitive building of the wings

Note: the rest-position is when supported by two out of three wings.

author: StratTone
title: Come on its a T.I.E. Defender!
review: How can you not like this set!  lol  The only complaints some may have if you ask me is the build since 3 major parts of the build are just repeats of wings.  So you may dock it a little but come on it is the way it looks.  I love this set and have no complaints.  Looks killer on the desk.

author: Legolover9531
title: Nice Ship
review:
I picked this set up during clerance at Target a couple months ago for $24.99 instead of $49.99, and it's a pretty good set.

 

Pros:

Minifigs

6 flick-fire missles

Easy Build

Good when bought on clerance

 

Cons:

Expensive set

Only room for one minifig in the cockpit

 

 

Playability: This is a great set for a space fight scene or just flying in general!

 

Parts: Nothing new for me (except the Pilot)

 

 

Overall, this is a good set, but don't buy it at the regular price.

author: trooper123
title: can not play with!
review:
I think this set it ok but it is very bad to play with.

Figures.

Tie fighter pilotis a very good figure much better than the old ones. The old ones just looked like shadow troopers.
Stormtrooper is the same as usual.

Features.

The reason why you carnt realy play with it is because the wings spin around.
Flick fire rockets.


Difficulties.

Wings some times fall apart.



Thanks for reading!

author: Shadowtrooper
title: BEST. TIE.  EVER.
review:
Shadowtrooper here.  This set is AWESOME!

Pros

  • Not 4, or even 5, but 6! 6 flick-fire missles!
  • Rotating thingy in cockpit keeps pilot upright
  • New (at least at the time of release) TIE pilot
  • Stormtrooper as a ground crew
  • Cool thruster piece at back
  • Red piece with holes on front behind pilot can be used as a blaster rack
  • BIG!

Cons

  • Cockpit flips upside down when cockpit is open in the same way it stays upright when closed
  • Missiles don't always work
  • Somewhat repetitive build
  • Pilot has no blaster.

Overall, this is an accurate depiction of the deadliest starfighter in the Imperial fleet, (Shields, hyperdrive, ion cannons, missiles, lasers, and more maneuverable than even a TIE Interceptor) and also a great set.  That's all. Shadowtrooper out!

=============END TRANSMISSION===========

author: tkettle9719
title: The Ultimate TIE
review:
I got this set from my stepdad's best friend, snd must say that it is an impressive set, albeit the evil price tag.

Pros

  • The new TIE series is rockin' the gray instead of the old blue.
  • The spinning function on this fighter is spot-on.

Cons

  • The resting position is not the best or the most secure ever.
  • The flick fire missiles are in abundance, which is nice, but don't work at all when the ship's wings are spinning.

This set is a great addition to the Star Wars Expanded Universe line, and is great for my dream of Lego X-Wing vs. TIE Fighter. Buy it, but it is expensive for what you get.

author: Chills
title: An interesting TIE set
review:
This set was on my wanted list for a while because I was a big fan of the PC game TIE Fighter, and I'm a collector of all things Imperial. Once I got the set I was a bit disappointed. There's really not much to it besides wings and a central cockpit.

Pros

  • Pro 1: TIE ships are pretty simple in design, wings and a ball cockpit, and this set follows that philosophy. So I guess a pro would be that LEGO used what limited data they had on the TIE Defender and made a set that matched the one from the SW universe.
  • Pro 2: It comes with two minifigures, an updated stormtrooper and a TIE pilot with actual TIE helmet (not a repainted stormtrooper helmet). Both minifigures are cool, but not very unique.
  • Pro 3: The designers used some creative techniques to get the tri-wing design. Not the easiest with LEGOS.

Cons

  • Con 1: The build was very repetitive. When I recently moved I disassembled almost all of my sets, but I left this one mostly intact. It wasn't a very enjoyable build, nothing made me go "hey this is pretty cool."
  • Con 2: There's not much to the set. Sure it is swooshable, but there's not much when it comes to playability. Its a little too simple.

I got this set on eBay for a pretty good deal, otherwise I'd not be too happy for paying a premium for this set. Its a cool addition to my TIE collection, but unless you must have every TIE out there you can probably pass on this one.

author: tvih
title: A quite nice representation of TIE Defender
review:
I wanted this set because the original TIE Fighter PC game was one of my favorites as a youth, and Defender was one of the flyable craft in it. Luckily, I managed to find the set for a decent price - for the most part at this point you're looking at buying second-hand and/or at inflated prices.

Box/Instructions

The box is nothing special. It features the same picture on three sides (front, left and right), with pics of the included mini figures on the top and front as well. At the back you get a different view of the Defender and figures, as well as a couple of images depicting its cockpit and missile functionality - as well as "ads" for a couple of other Star Wars sets. Oddly enough the upper portion of the back and front depicts three clone troopers, which obviously are from a different Star Wars era than the Defender. But as the new TIE Fighter box has Darth Maul in it too and so forth, I guess this is not the only box with that oddity.

The instructions are clear enough. You won't be left wondering what you are supposed to do next, especially as the build is quite straightforward.

Parts

The parts list doesn't feature many interesting things. Since it's a largely symmetrical craft, you get a lot of the same parts, so the variety isn't huge. This shouldn't be a problem if you're buying the set for the sake of getting this exact ship like I did, but if you're looking to use the parts for something else, then you might be disappointed - depends on what you're looking to build, of course!

Given the relatively nice size of the ship, the actual part count isn't that high either at just over 300 parts.

Minifigures

Included are a pilot of course, and as a very nice bonus a stormtrooper as well. He doesn't - and isn't supposed to - fit inside the ship, so he's indeed just a bonus. He's my first stormtrooper, hopefully with many more to come, though current sets don't offer many choices for getting a standard stormtrooper - you're pretty much left with the Endor Battle Pack, and even that has only one for a quite steep parts per buck ratio.

The pilot looks nice too, and is apparently a bit different from Imperial pilots in other sets, for example compared to the pilot found in both the new TIE Fighter and the TIE Interceptor & Death Star sets.

The build

It should come as no surprise that the build is a bit repetitive, since the ship is indeed quite symmetrical. So it's not the most fun or unique building experience in that sense. But that's indeed to be expected, and can't be helped given the ship's design.

It's also a straightforward build in general, so no big surprises or difficulties to be found.

The completed model

Even after having seen all the images in comparison to the mini figures, I found the model to be slightly larger than I had expected. It looks quite good, and acceptably similar to the original ship. The rolling cockpit - it always stays "upright" - is an interesting addition.

I did wonder why the ship only has two lasers, since it's supposed to hae two lasers AND four ion cannons. It does have six missiles, while it should have only four. They're of the "flick-fire" variety, though in practise you'd have to "wear down" the parts quite a bit to actually make them "flickable" - as it is, I have to pull with some force to remove them from the "launchers". But as a display model, like it is in my case, that's of no consequence.

One very minor thing is that the wing sections - the six long portions - are ever so slightly wobbly. It's not a big deal - for a display model, it's fine as it is, and when playing with the model... parts tend to get knocked around a bit anyway, a few millimeters here or there doesn't really matter.

One last quibble is that the pilot doesn't have any controls, which seems a bit of an odd choice.

As for playability in general, other than the mentioned issue with the launchers I don't really see any problems. Many people have stated that the model is awkward to hold when playing with it. I'm not sure why. I found it perfectly natural to grab the ship around the engine fuselage, it only needs one hand and it seems to be it should work fine even for someone with smaller hands. A very small person who might not have the strength to hold it that way for very long can just support from under the ship with the other hand.

Summary

In summary it's a nice model whether you're getting it to play with or just to keep on display. It's not perfect, and especially the building process isn't that thrilling, but it's still a good addition to any Star Wars collection.
